title: Good success stories on Hendersonville consignment front
text:
Good success stories on Hendersonville consignment front Mary Hance , mscheap@tennessean.com 3:37 p.m. CDT October 8, 2015 Carlos Alfaro gets help from The Mens Room owner Kathy Wallace as he puts together part of his college wardrobe at the Hendersonville men's consignment shop's new location. (Photo: Mary Hance / The Tennessean) 274 CONNECT 5 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
I love shopping, I love consignment, I love Hendersonville and I love success stories. 
So today, I give you news of some happy relocations and expansions of three consignment stores in Hendersonville. 
Up and Down Closet 
First up is the Up and Down Closet, which has relocated to a spot next to Publix in Hendersonville. This plus-size ladies consignment shop in Hendersonville, which opened in 2007 on a shoestring and a prayer, was the vision of six plus-size ladies who were tired of not having a good place to buy cute, affordable clothes and saw a need for plus-size clothing. In a previous column, I described it as "one of local cheapdom's best success stories." 
The entrepreneurial ladies had no real retail experience (other than liking to shop), so as a trial run, they signed a lease for six months. At the end of the lease, whoever wanted to continue the business could. Two became owners, two became employees, and now, more than eight years later, the ownership is all with Sherry Lawler. 
The most recent challenge came when Lawler was told that the Kmart center, where the shop had been from the beginning, was to be torn down to make way for a new Hendersonville Kroger. The news was daunting at first, but Lawler's real estate search turned up some great space just across Gallatin Road, at 240 East Main St. (next to Publix) and business continues to grow. The shop, which is 500 square feet larger than the old one, now has 1,300 consignors â€” some of whom bring in a couple of pieces at a time and some bring in as many as 200. 
This shop specializes in ladies sizes 14 and up to 30-32 and 6X, as well as shoes, handbags and accessories. Walk-ins are accepted, but appointments are highly recommended. The split is 50/50. The brands are all over the place (Cato and Old Navy, as well as Chico's, J.Jill, Coldwater Creek, St. John), And that mix is by design, Lawler said. "We want to be somewhere that people with any size pocketbook can shop." 
She added that "most of the people who shop and consign here have gained and lost the weight two or three times. It is fluid. That is why we are called what we are called... 'Up and Down Closet' is the name." Details: http://www.upanddowncloset.com or 615-264-6569. Be sure to sign up for the customer loyalty card 
The Mens Room 
Another happy ending was the move of The Mens Room to a new location at 109 Walton Ferry Road in Hendersonville as a result of the same Kmart redevelopment . This men's consignment shop, that started out in space adjoining the Up and Down Closet, has ended up in a great storefront on Walton Ferry Road, with 400 more square feet and a better setup. 
Owner Kathy Wallace started the shop in March 2010 as a consignment store for big and tall men's clothing, but now caters to men of all sizes, with the larger sizes making up roughly half the store. She has more than 900 consignors and carries shoes, ties and other men's accessories, as well as casual and business clothing for men in sizes small up to as large as she can get. The split is 50/50 between the shop and the consignors. 
During my visit, young Carlos Alfaro was preparing for his freshman year at MTSU and was racking up an entire new wardrobe for pennies on the dollar, with some help from Wallace. Alfaro's clothing haul included 18 items for a total for right at $90, including Hollister jeans, a Gap hoodie, several new-looking polos, a nice leather belt and more. 
"Our new location is one-and-a-half times bigger and $12 a month cheaper," Wallace said, noting that another plus for her new location is that there are lots of good affordable eating places nearby, including Thank God Donuts, which I have to say, was amazing! Details: www.themensrm.com or 615-431-2438 . 
Bloom Designer Finds 
My third update has to do with Bloom Designer Finds ladies consignment shop, which just doubled the size of its shop at 117 Stadium Drive. "We had 1,100 square feet, and the space to the left of us came open and so we took it and now have 2,200 square feet," said Ashley Steenhoven, who owns the store with her husband, Aaron. 
The couple first opened in January 2014 and now have almost 600 consignors. Their target customer is aged 15-55, which they attract with brands like Tory Burch, Coach, Michael Kors, Lululemon, Anthropology, J.Crew etc. There are lots of designer jeans (brands like Joe's, J Brand, Citizens of Humanity, 7 For All Mankind and more) with most priced under $55, and the additional space also gives them room to carry some brand new merchandise like Umgee and Entro in the under $40 price range. 
I was happy to hear that they were also offering a special section of brands like Chico's, Jones New York, and Eileen Fisher brands to attract additional shoppers (as in older ones like me). 
"We are also adding a designer section," Steenhoven said, explaining that shoppers seem to like having higher-end brands curated in a special area. The shop includes shoes, scarves, jewelry and lots and lots of handbags, that she says sell as fast as they come in. 
The Steenhovens long-term plan is to open a sister shop in Williamson County and they are introducing themselves to that market through a free VIP pickup service, where she will work by appointment to come to consignors' homes to pick up their pieces. "I do about five a week," she said. "It gives us a lot of good inventory. We hope to eventually open in Brentwood or Franklin." 
Details. See Bloom Designer Finds on Facebook or 615-477-2378 
Reach Ms. Cheap at 615-259-8282. Follow her at Tennessean.com/mscheap or on Facebook/MsCheap , on Twitter @Ms_Cheap , and catch her every Thursday at 11 a.m. on WTVF-Channel 5's "Talk of the Town." 
Other consignment shops in Hendersonville 
Second Time Around 
One of the longest-operating ladies consignment shops in the Midstate is Second Time Around at 121 Indian Lake Road, in the Maple Row Shopping Center. Peggy Armstrong is celebrating her 21st year as owner of this popular consignment shop, which has been in business for about 30 years. There are about 800 consignors. In addition to name brand causal and ladies business clothing, this store has a large consignment bridal boutique with at least 200 dresses in stock at any given time, with almost none costing more than $400. The store also carries prom dresses, pageant wear and formals, as well as shoes, handbags, accessories and jewelry. Details: 615-822-6961 or www.secondtimearoundbypeggy.com 
Little Ones 'n ReRuns 
Little Ones 'n ReRuns childrens boutique, at 235 East Main St. has been in business for 15 years and is owned by Tanya McPherson. The shop carries clothing from newborns to size 16, plus baby equipment,and gift items, including some new accessories such as bags and bows. Don't miss the $1.99 rack. The split is 50/50 Details: 615-826-7050 or Little Ones 'n ReRuns on Facebook . 
Ms. Cheap's Four easy tips for consignment shoppers 
Get on your favorite shops' email lists to keep up with sales, and specials 
Follow the shops on their Facebook pages 
Shop often since additional merchandise is being added almost daily 
Get to know the owners and manager so they can let you know when something you are interested in comes in. 274 CONNECT 5 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://tnne.ws/1RwAKuR MORE STORIES
